fields.description:
We're running a Crucible trial, and we're a Mac shop. Apple just pushed Safari 5, then 5.0.1 in rapid succession.

Unfortunately, the Crucible review UI is now broken under S5: you can no longer click on diffs to add comments (the whole point of the product). Can you reproduce on your side, and do you have an ETA to fix?

No appropriate screen cap: the diff displays OK, it's just completely dead to mouse clicks.

Thanks,
Mark
fields.summary: Crucible reviews broken under Safar 5+5.0.1

fields.description:
When I clicked the "Suggest reviewers" button for a view I created earlier today, it told me that one user had touched 99% of the file and another user had touched 1% of the file.

The reality, however, was that the user with 99% of the file only moved the file from one package to another, and when I looked at the history of the file, actually, more changes were done by a *third* user, which Crucible had listed as 0%.

I don't think that this kind of minor refactoring should count for any lines of code at all, except possibly one line for the updated package line.
fields.summary: "Suggest reviewer" should not take into account lines of code acquired by moving the file

fields.description:
for historical reasons, user data is stored in two places in FE/CRU:
- infinityDB stores username, email, various prefs
- crucdb stores username, id, email, and various prefs

*UPDATE* users are now stored in crucdb, however groups, watches, etc are still stored in infdb0. This needs to move across as well so infdb0 can be decommissioned.

this legacy is leading to death by a thousand cuts in support and maintenance.

Unify user data into the crudb. 
 - migrate data from infinitydb to crudb and decommission infinity DB0
 - unify UserManager and CrucibleUserManager: separate security/auth questions into new SecurityManager and move all other user management into a single manager class.
 
see also FE-2707
fields.summary: Unify user, group, watches and notification management / storage in FECRU

fields.description:
It would be nice if you could submit a review to not just a single person, but to a pre-defined group of reviewers. Then any member of that group could perform the review and once marked complete from that group member the group itself would be satisfied. 

I see this as useful your organization is modular and you need to submit code to say a group of DBA's or UI Developers to review. It could also be useful if you're a small, and very busy organization, where you can't rely on someone getting to your review in a timely manner. By submitting to a group, it's hoped that at least one member of the group has a moment they can submit feedback.
fields.summary: Allow reviews to be submitted to a pre-defined group of reviewers

fields.description:
From http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257348716#257348716

The last reviewer to complete generates an {{AllReviewersCompletedEvent}}, instead of a {{ReviewerCompletedEvent}}. The {{AllReviewersCompletedEvent}} does not contain a way of determining the originator of the event. 

Two possible solutions:
1. The last reviewer to complete should generate both a {{ReviewerCompleteEvent}} and {{AllReviewersCompletedEvent}}. This is the most correct solution, but will cause disruption downstream for event consumers since they'll be getting two events instead of one for review completion. This does have the advantage of no API change though.

2. Expose the originator in the {{AllReviewersCompletedEvent}}. Not as disruptive, since the number of events generated will stay the same (although the API will change).
fields.summary: ReviewerCompletedEvent not fired for last reviewer to complete

fields.description:
Some customers would like ability to flag which reviewers *must* complete a review before it can be summarised. 

Other reviewers who are not flagged as a mandatory reviewer wouldn't need to complete the review before it is summarised. 


----


{panel:title=2018.08.27 Status update}
Thank you very much for all your feedback provided so far. One of Fisheye/Crucible developers created a plugin providing this functionality, you can find it on Marketplace:

https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1219472/mandatory-reviewers-for-crucible

At the moment we do not plan to bundle this plugin into Crucible, we would love to hear your feedback first. Some of the things we would like to discuss are:
 * mandatory reviewers configurable per project or per review?
 * if per project then would you prefer groups or permission schemes?
 * if per review then how you'd like to distinguish them from non-mandatory ones?
 * how do you see having mandatory reviewers vs review moderator?
 * how many mandatory reviewers must complete the review (all / one / N)?

Feel free to try it out and comment under this feature request. The plugin is compatible with Crucible 4.3 and higher. 
{panel}
fields.summary: Mandatory Reviewers

fields.description:
We need to make it clear in our documentation that HSQLDB is shipped only as a convenience for evaluators; for production systems we strongly recommend an external database, such as PostgreSQL. 

HSQLDB is a single-threaded, in-memory database that will not perform at scale.

This information should appear on these pages (at least):

Support Platforms
Recommended Configuration for Crucible
fields.summary: nowhere in our doco do we say that HSQLDB is not recommended for production systems

*Timebox to 1 day*

* exact matches before partial matches
* fall back to newest first
* file matches before changesets

fields.description:
Reviews are spitting errors and diff source is failing to render in the following situation:
# Create a Review that links to an existing JIRA
# Move the JIRA to a different project
# Open the review, it will fail to load the source, and has the following error rendered in a hidden div in the page:
{noformat} javax.el.ELException: com.cenqua.fisheye.util.LRUCache$ValueFactoryException: org.apache.xmlrpc.XmlRpcException: java.lang.Exception: com.atlassian.jira.rpc.exception.RemotePermissionException: This issue does not exist or you don't have permission to view it.{noformat}

In order to complete this story, please verify and fix this bug, as well as check the behaviour of Crucible when a JIRA instance is down.
fields.summary: Review source doesn't render if a linked JIRA is moved
Verify that our wadl documentation generation still works

fields.description:
When viewing the snippets table, the column headings used are the regular review columns (State, Review, Owner, Name, Files, Comments, Age, Due, Reviewers).  These should be updated to be appropriate for snippets:
* remove State (irrelevant for snippets), files, due, and reviewers
* rename "Review" to "Snippet"
* rename "Owner" to "Created By"
* rename "Age" to "Date"
* Display date created instead of age in date column
* reorder columns to be Snippet, Name, Created By, Date
fields.summary: Column headers on snippet table need to be changed

fields.description: Sorting the status field on all open snippets table causes text to change (inserts line break in 'open snippet').  See screenflow.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# [Configure LDAP Authentication|http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/hoCDBQ]
# If we have 2 users named "test" and "test " (with trailing space) in LDAP, it will create 2 different accounts in Crucible after all.
 
We should check for trailing spaces when adding users from external authentication.
fields.summary: Doesn't check for trailing spaces when adding new users with external authentication

fields.description:
Currently Crucible permission will be automatically added to a new user if a crucible seat is available. This sometimes results in the wrong users getting Crucible permission. 

An admin toggle could prevent the automatic assignment of crucible permission to new users, so that an admin could manually assign crucible seats to users.


request via http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257347410
fields.summary: toggle the automatic assignment of crucible seats to new users

fields.description:
We perform all our code reviews before commit. This means the only way we have to attach changes, is either by uploading the files directly, or by uploading a SVN patch. 

When we upload the SVN patch files, we can see the diffs, however, it appears that the changed code shows up at incorrect 
lines. 

For example, this is what the curcible shows
!cru1.JPG!
 
When I apply this patch on the checked out branch it shows up correctly

!svn1.JPG!


If you notice between the two images, you will notice that the lines are transposed. The tortoise diff shows the correct position. This has been verified by looking into the actual file, once the patch was downloaded from the crucible review and applied to the unmodified source file. 

!file1.JPG!

Also, looking at the SVN diff file, I see the following

!diff1.JPG!

If these line numbers are not correct, crucible is unusable.

Also, It appears that when we upload the files, the diffs do not show up.
fields.summary: Precommit patch files generate incorrect diffs.

fields.description: When opening a review we get a NullPointerException. We have this problem only on a few reviews. Also a server restart does not help. See attachment for a stack trace.
fields.summary: NullPointerException when opening a review.

fields.description: It would be nice in .java files to have annotations displayed differently.
fields.summary: Syntax Highlight for annotations

fields.description:
When someone closes a review that you (as a reviewer) have not yet completed, it would be good to still be able to see what you had/hadn't completed, rather than marking all the files as complete.

I dont want to reoopen it unless I really need to, as it will reoopen it for all participating reviewers, but there is no easy way to tell if "I really need to"
fields.summary: Ability to see uncompleted files in a completed review

fields.description:
If you upload a badly formatted patch (e.g. with leading whitespace) via REST it is accepted without issue and added to the review, but the files do not show up as revisions !http://img.skitch.com/20100712-c3cm64b3eh1wt572w65ib9c2rx.jpg! Patch: {noformat}

Generate a PDF export of a review

-
@@ -60,4 +60,4 @@
- \ No newline at end of file + ]]> {noformat}
fields.summary: Uploading patches via REST do not add revisions to review when the patch contains leading whitespace

fields.description:
Various performance issues exist if a gigantic review is created (e.g. CRUC-2042.)  The one we are hit with specifically is that the repository will remain on "Indexing review data" indefinitely after a large review is created (we left it for a week and it never finished.)

Unfortunately, if the "Automatic Review Creator" plugin is present, we don't really get a choice over whether to create them or not, so if any user does a large commit, e.g.:

* tagging / branching operations, of the sort which Subversion shows as a multi-file change instead of a single copy
* merging vendor changes into the local repository

The review which is created automatically from this will make the server effectively unusable.  This becomes a huge hindrance when you have several such commits to make, as the workflow for getting rid of the reviews and bringing the system back to stable takes a while each time.

Since there does appear to be some upper limit to the size of reviews, it would be nice if this plugin would not create reviews if they are above this limit.  I haven't determined where the limit is, exactly, but I know that it's less than 10,000 and more than 100.
fields.summary: Automatic Review Creator: Ability to not create a review if it will cause a problem with Crucible

fields.description:
If you have your timezone set in FishEye server settings, then the backup time would based on the timezone. However, the backup.zip would have the date which same as your server (OS).
The time showing in backup UI, e.g "Current local server time is: 16:41" is indicating your server (OS) time.
Perhaps I should come out an example for this, lets say,
your server(OS) time = 09:00
FishEye server setting time zone = timezone X (which is -1 hour different of your OS time, when your OS in 09:00, your timezone should be 08:00)
and you set the backup time to 08:30. Backup will be performed at 08:30 timezone X, which is OS time 09:30. You will find your backup.zip dated dd/MM/yyyy 09:30
fields.summary: Inconsistency time for scheduled backup

fields.description:
After upgrading from 1.6.6 to 2.3.3 I've noticed that any Crucible reviews that have Patch files associated to them will lose their diff content.  Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a new Review in 1.6.6 and attach a Patch file to the review.
2. Perform an upgrade from 1.6.6 to 2.3.3.
3. Start the new version of Crucible and view the review created in step one.
4. Click on one of the files to view the diff and Crucible will return "No Change".

The issue is that after the upgrade, some of the paths in the {{cru_stored_path}} get newlines appended to them which cause Crucible to silently fail to load the diff.  For example:

{noformat}
 cru_path_id |                  cru_path
----------------------------------------------+-------------+--------------------------------------------
           1 | /test/file1
|
           2 | /test/file2
|     
           3 | /test/file3
|
           4 | /test/file4
|          
{noformat}

In testing it appears that removing the newline at the end of {{cru_path}} will solve the problem.  A restart of Crucible is required, after running the following SQL statement:

{noformat}UPDATE cru_stored_path SET cru_path = replace(cru_path, '\n', '');{noformat}

This is a pretty nasty upgrade bug that we should try to address in future versions.
fields.summary: Upgrade from 1.6 to 2.3 results in Patch content losing diffs
